message.content: This question requires knowledge of the physical adaptations that ducks have for swimming. Ducks have extra foot skin, which helps them to propel themselves through the water. This extra skin acts like a paddle and provides more surface area for pushing against the water, allowing ducks to swim efficiently. Option (A) is incorrect because the space between their toes does not directly contribute to their swimming ability. Option (B) is true, but it does not explain why ducks are excellent swimmers. Option (C) is also true, but it does not provide a specific reason for their swimming ability.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the anatomy of ducks and their adaptations for swimming. Ducks have a layer of extra skin on their feet, known as webs, which helps them to generate more thrust in the water and propel themselves forward. This extra foot skin is an adaptation that allows them to be excellent swimmers. Option (A) is incorrect because having a space between their toes does not directly contribute to their swimming ability. Option (B) is partially correct, as ducks are indeed buoyant and resilient in the water, but this does not solely explain their swimming ability. Option (C) is inaccurate because the width of their feet alone does not determine their swimming ability.

This question requires some basic knowledge about the anatomy of ducks and how it aids in their swimming abilities. Ducks have webbed feet, which means that their toes are connected by a thin membrane of skin. This extra foot skin helps to increase surface area and provides better propulsion in the water, making them excellent swimmers. Option (A) is incorrect because having a space between their toes would actually hinder their swimming ability. Option (B) is partially true, as ducks are buoyant due to their body shape and feathers, but it does not explain why they are excellent swimmers. Option (C) is also partially true, as ducks do have wide feet, but it is not the main reason for their swimming ability.
